report_title: Musical Instrument Rental Services Industry Report
executive_summary: Musical instrument rental services include brick-and-mortar and online businesses engaged in short and long-term musical instrument rentals for individuals, schools, businesses, private events and government buyers. Companies have endured volatile demand through the current period, especially amid the pandemic. Plummeting consumer confidence alongside school closures and online learning limited opportunities for music programs, slashing demand for rentals and leading to monumental revenue drops. However, individuals had more free time and fewer entertainment options during lockdown restrictions; stimulus checks also contributed to more robust consumer confidence, encouraging consumers to rent and learn an instrument. Even so, climbing inflation has caused consumers to prioritize saving; ending lockdown restrictions has also enabled individuals to

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Pandemic Throws the Industry into Disarray
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The pandemic created new challenges for musical instrument rental services. Since the industry heavily relies on demand from K-12 students and schools, online classes slammed growth in 2020. Many schools tightened budgets, cutting music programs during this period. However, excess leisure time during the pandemic encouraged adults and students to pick up instruments, leading to skyrocketing demand in 2021 and offsetting declines from 2020. Stimulus checks from the Federal government also supported consumer rentals.

Consumers make larger, leisure-related purchases when consumer confidence is high; consumers spend more frequently on musical instrument rentals when they have excess cash. Climbing inflation following the pandemic has posed a clear threat to musical instrument rental services; individuals have allocated more toward savings and essential items, like groceries and rent, while spending less on leisure, like music lessons and rental instruments.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE RETURN TO WORK THREATENS INSTRUMENT RENTALS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Individuals have had less time to practice musical instruments following the pandemic as they return to in-person work. Ending lockdown restrictions has also given consumers access to more leisure and entertainment options, cutting into demand for musical instruments. This trend has forced many companies to cut back, leading to lower employment figures. Nonemployers have especially struggled to compete with prominent brands with strong reputations, causing companies to exit the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: COMPANIES REMAIN RESILIANT TO ONLINE TRENDS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Brick-and-mortar musical instrument rental services will remain steady despite rampant growth in e-commerce during the pandemic. Musicians largely prefer to play and test instruments before renting; this action is impossible when renting online. Even so, online rentals may grow popular with less experienced musicians, especially students. Companies must emphasize employee knowledge and expertise to carve out a stable position in this evolving landscape. These core strengths will enable the industry to succeed through the outlook period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: DECLINING FEDERAL FUNDING WILL THREATEN GROWTH
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Plummeting Federal funding for creative arts will indirectly cripple musical instrument rentals. Lower creative arts funding could result in fewer public lesson programs and fewer opportunities for musical careers; both of these eventualities would discourage people from learning instruments. However, government funding for primary and secondary education will climb, enabling schools to allocate more money toward rejuvenating music programs, counteracting decreased funding for creative arts. Similarly, strengthening consumer confidence will encourage individuals to spend on leisure activities, like learning an instrument. Students returning to school following the pandemic will remain the largest driver for musical instrument rental services.

industry_definition: The industry's establishments are primarily engaged in the rental of musical instruments. These rental services do not include revenue from establishments that also retail musical instruments and miscellaneous gear.
key_trends: Many individuals started to learn instruments during the pandemic.
Lifting lockdown restrictions and weak consumer confidence have counteracted pandemic-era growth.
Recovering economic conditions will support growth through the outlook period. Greater primary and secondary education funding will also support growth.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Individual consumers are the primary source of demand for music instrument rental services; parents and guardians renting instruments for children is a major driver of demand in this market.
Public and private schools are the largest portion of other buyers for this industry.
Public schools, especially, rely on government K-12 and creative arts funding to rent instruments and keep music programs running in schools.

products_and_services.product_description: Guitar and Piano are Popular with Students
WOODWIND INSTRUMENTS REMAIN POPULAR IN SCHOOLS
DRUMS AND PERCUSSION INSTRUMENTS DISPLAY STEADY DEMAND
Guitar and Piano are Popular with Students
THE LACK OF ORCHESTRA PROGRAMS HOLDS BACK DEMAND FOR STRING INSTRUMENTS
BRASS INSTRUMENTS ARE INCREASINGLY POPULAR WITH YOUNG AMERICANS
Some rental companies also provide other equipment, like DJ and sound equipment. These products are especially popular with event planners and performers.

tier_1_suppliers: Musical Instrument & Supplies Stores in the US
Online Music Instrument Sales in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Acoustic & Electric Guitar Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Most individuals are more likely to rent or purchase an instrument during positive economic conditions, while consumers will focus on essential goods as consumer confidence falters.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Government Funding for Primary and Secondary Education
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Schools are a driving force in demand for instrument rentals as most k-12 students rent instruments rather than buy them.
K-12 students have historically been the largest demographic of musical instrument rentals.
Since many instruments have wood components, the price of sawmill lumber and wood impacts sales and profit.

basis_points.basis_description: Companies must provide superior services to attract demand.
A diverse inventory of sanitized, high-quality instruments will give companies a competitive edge.

Brick-and-mortar stores face mounting competition from online rentals. Skilled employees and consumers' desire to try instruments before renting will prevent online options from overtaking traditional rental services.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages are among the industry's largest expenses; employees must be knowledgeable about different instrument rentals and often play multiple instruments, too.
Many companies carry high insurance costs to protect purchased instruments – this expense takes up the majority of costs for musical instrument rental services.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patent technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations.
The concentration of technologies is high in this industry. This suggests that industry operators have exposure to potentially unforeseen areas of innovation.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Less public funding for music programs
volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for musical instrument rental services largely relies on K-12 students and the accessibility of scholastic and other public music programs.

FAQs.question: What is the key factor causing high revenue volatility in the musical instrument rental industry?
FAQs.answer: Less public funding for music programs creates volatility.

FAQs.question: What is the level of regulation in the musical instrument rental industry?
FAQs.answer: The regulation level is low and steady.

FAQs.question: What is the level of industry assistance for the musical instrument rental industry?
FAQs.answer: The industry assistance level is low and steady.
